title: [金融戰線] 一人一信阻殺中共新疆人面識別企業IPO

replies.msg:
我哋係金融界嘅一班手足，而家正式宣佈開闢金融戰線。

長話短說，我哋制訂左一套war plan，可以絕殺一間中共人面識別嘅龍頭企業。依家只需要你用一分鐘時間做以下動作，呢間叫做曠視(Megvii)嘅中共戰略企業就可以正式收皮。

長話短說，曠視目前申請緊喺香港上市，今個禮拜四港交所就會開會決定批唔批准佢上市。曠視呢間野之所以咁特別，就係因為美國啱啱十月將佢加入制裁名單，懲罰佢係新疆大搞針對維吾爾族嘅人面識別工程。

發生左咁大件事，正常港交所係會hold一hold住唔俾上市，只不過事件涉及中共戰略企業，港交所唔夠膽行第一步郁佢，所以明知自己冒險幫緊一間美國制裁嘅中共企業集資，上上下下都係敢怒不敢言。呢個時候我哋嘅助攻就嚟得非常關鍵，我哋要用返一套金融同法律嘅語言，向港交所指控曠視違反上市規則，根本係唔適合香港上市。我地成功嘅話，呢間中共龍頭企業將會面臨數以十億計嘅損失，一夜收皮！

Email已經為你地draft好，只需要你哋用一分鐘時間send出去。港交所星期四cob就要決定俾唔俾佢上市，所以各位一定要快（同埋記得一定要連埋最底嘅參考資料）！

#############################

To: WEIR Andrew Walter Bougourd Ross (andrew.weir@kpmg.com)
BRIEN Peter Wilhelm Hubert (peter.brien@slaughterandmay.com)
LI Xiaojia, Charles (charlesli@hkex.com.hk )
Cc: info@hkex.com.hk

Dear Listing Committee,

I am writing to lodge a complaint about the listing application of Megvii Technology Limited (“Megvii”). Put bluntly, Megvii fails to make adequate disclosure of material sanctions risks related to its business in the listing document, in breach of Main Board Listing Rules and the Guidance Letter HKEX-GL101-19. This casts doubt on whether Megvii is suitable for listing.

Sanctions risk arising from the addition of Megvii to the U.S. Entity List
On 7th October 2019, the U.S. Department of Commerce added Megvii to the Entity List, thereby imposing license requirements on any transaction in which items are to be exported, re-exported, or transferred to Megvii[1]. A direct consequence of this sanction is that Megvii has lost access American components critical to its supply chain, including x86 servers and graphic processing units (“GPU”), according to Mr. Yin Qi, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Megvii[2]. It is expected that Megvii will struggle to find substitutes as good-performing as x86 servers from Intel and AMD and GPUs from AMD and Nvidia, in view of the underdevelopment of local suppliers in China.

Notwithstanding the statement by Mr. Yin, Megvii fails to disclose this material sanction risk in its listing document. Specifically, Megvii documents only those risk factors marginally related to sanctions risks in the Application Proof, including the following[3]:
i. “Any flaws or misuse of AI technologies”;
ii. “Rumors or negative publicity”;
iii. “Export control and economic or trade restrictions that was imposed on Huawei and a number of its non-U.S. affiliates”;
iiii. “Changes in international trade policies and barriers to trade or the emergence of a trade war”.

While (i) covers the risk of misuse of Megvii’s technology by third parties (including the Chinese government), it does not address the incurrence of sanctions risks as a consequence of such misuse. Similarly, (iv) attends to only those risks arising from the “trade war”, i.e. is “changes to trade policies, treaties and tariffs”, but not from the “tech war” per se. Sanctions risks are touched upon in (iii), albeit only in relation to Huawei and its affiliates. It is in (ii) that Megvii really warns of the possibility of U.S. export restrictions, although the stress is put more on reputation risks than sanctions risk. More important, (ii) has not been updated to reflect the material fact that the Entity List-related sanctions risk facing Megvii is no longer an imagined risk but a realized one. This raises questions as to whether Megvii has breached Main Board Listing Rule 2.13(2), by purposely omitting material facts of an unfavourable nature and/or failing to accord them with appropriate significance in the listing document. In addition, Megvii may have breached Paragraph 3.7 of the Guidance Letter HKEX-GL101-19 for failing to prominently disclose details of the sanctioned activities, including their financial and operational impact, in the “Summary”, “Risk Factors” and “Business” sections of its listing document. In view of the foregoing, there are grave concerns over whether Megvii is indeed suitable for listing pursuant to Paragraph 8.04 of the Listing Rules.

replies.msg: 點解唔上左市等美國制裁港交所

For the sake of completeness, it appears unlikely that Megvii would be removed from the U.S. Entity List anytime soon. According to the U.S. Department of Commerce, Megvii was sanctioned for “enabling activities contrary to the foreign policy interests of the United States” pursuant to § 744.11(b) of the Export Administration Regulations. Furthermore, it is curious to note that the “foreign policy interests” under consideration here are defined very loosely, concerning not the direct national security interests of the U.S. but, indirectly, “human rights violations and abuses in the implementation of China’s campaign of repression, mass arbitrary detention, and high-technology surveillance against Uighurs, Kazakhs, and other members of Muslim minority groups” in Xinjiang. With such an expansive notion of foreign policy interests, the Entity List decision assumes a political dimension. In other words, the burden of proof falls on Megvii to make not only a legal case that it is not “enabling” Beijing’s repression in Xinjiang, but also a political case that being removed from the Entity List is in the national interests of the U.S. at any given point in time. While I should not prejudge Megvii’s probability of success in such an appeal [4], I am appalled by Megvii’s failure to at least provide an update on sanctions risk in its listing document, to the detriment of investors who may not be aware of severe implications of this sanction for Megvii’s financial position and business operations.

Sanctions risk arising from other sources

Apart from Entity List-related sanctions risk, Megvii has also failed to document other types of sanctions risks incurred as a result of its business operations. Notably, Megvii could fall foul of the Sergei Magnitsky Rule of Law Accountability Act of 2012 (“Magnitsky Act”)[5]. Should the U.S. decide to sanction Megvii for its alleged human rights abuse in Xinjiang under the Magnitsky Act, Megvii will face the freezing of assets, including all those assets found under possession or control by U.S. financial institutions, pursuant to Section 406 of the Magnitsky Act. Since the Hong Kong dollar is backed by the U.S. dollar under the Linked Exchange Rate System, any financial transaction with Megvii on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong will be bound to go through U.S. financial institutions at some point, and will be seized under the Magnitsky Act[6]. If materialized, Megvii’s ability to continue its operations would be severely undermined, not to mention the considerable reputational, if not operational risk caused to the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (“HKEX”). For these reasons, the HKEX should not approve Megvii’s listing on the basis of Paragraph 3.8 of the Guidance Letter HKEX-GL101-19.

Final remarks

. Generally speaking, Megvii will face considerable geopolitical risks in view of the long-term confrontation between the U.S. and China. In 2017, the U.S. listed China as a “challenger” alongside Russia, Iran, North Korea and jihadist terrorist groups[7]. In the so-called Section 301 Report of 2018, the U.S. further made an issue of China’s laws, policies, and practices related to “intellectual property, innovation, and technology that may encourage or require the transfer of American technology and intellectual property to enterprises in China or that may otherwise negatively affect American economic interests,” with a special reference to Beijing’s Made in China 2025 plan to develop high-technology industries[8]. There is every chance that Megvii will be caught not just by sanctions risks, but also geopolitical risks in general, which will have unpredictable consequences for Megvii’s financial position and business operations. Geopolitical risks, however, are not touched upon in Megvii’s listing document.

In light of all of the above, there are valid reasons to believe that Megvii is not suitable for listing. I strongly urge you to consider the case of Megvii’s listing application in the most prudent manner.

Regards,


Notes:
[1] U.S. Department of Commerce Bureau of Industry and Security, “Addition of Certain Entities to the Entity List”, Federal Register, Vol. 84, No. 196, Oct 9 2019. https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2019-10-09/pdf/2019-22210.pdf
[2] South China Morning Post, “Megvii CEO says US ban will hit its supply of servers and could disturb IPO but it is ‘ready for the fight’”, 14 Oct 2019.
https://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3032815/megvii-ceo-says-us-ban-will-be-challenge-chinese-ai-start-ups-plans
[3] Application Proof of Megvii Technology Limited, Sponsored by Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan and Citibank, p. 39, 41-43.

[4] I understood that Megvii is currently appealing the U.S.Entity List decision. See Bloomberg, ‘China AI Startup Megvii Pushes Ahead With IPO Despite U.S. Blacklisting,’ 16 October 2019. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-16/china-ai-startup-pushes-ahead-with-ipo-despite-u-s-blacklisting
[5] U.S. Department of the Treasury, ‘Russia and Moldova Jackson-Vanik Repeal and Sergei Magnitsky Rule of Law Accountability Act of 212’. https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/pl112_208.pdf
[6] Section 406 c(2) provides that each financial institution that is a United States person and has within its possession or control assets that are property or interests in property of a person who is on the list required by section 404(a) if such property and interests in property are in the United States is required to certify to the Treasury Secretary that, to the best of the knowledge of the financial institution, the financial institution has frozen all assets within the possession or control of the financial institu- tion that are required to be frozen pursuant to subsection (a).
[7] President of the United States, National Security Strategy of the United States of America, December 2017, p. 25.
https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/NSS-Final-12-18-2017-0905.pdf
[8] Executive Office of the President of the United States of America, ‘Findings of the Investigation into China’s Acts, Policies, and Practices Related to Technology Transfer, Intellectual Property, and Innovation Under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974’, March 22 2018, p. 4, 10.
https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/Section%20301%20FINAL.PDF

長話短說，曠視目前申請緊喺香港上市，今個禮拜四港交所就會開會決定批唔批准佢上市。曠視呢間野之所以咁特別，就係因為美國啱啱十月將佢加入制裁名單，懲罰佢係新疆大搞針對維吾爾族嘅人面識別工程。

發生左咁大件事，正常港交所係會hold一hold住唔俾上市，只不過事件涉及中共戰略企業，港交所唔夠膽行第一步郁佢，所以明知自己冒險幫緊一間美國制裁嘅中共企業集資，上上下下都係敢怒不敢言。呢個時候我哋嘅助攻就嚟得非常關鍵，我哋要用返一套金融同法律嘅語言，向港交所指控曠視違反上市規則，根本係唔適合香港上市。我地成功嘅話，呢間中共龍頭企業將會面臨數以十億計嘅損失，一夜收皮！

Email已經為你地draft好，只需要你哋用一分鐘時間send出去。港交所星期四cob就要決定俾唔俾佢上市，所以各位一定要快（同埋記得一定要連埋最底嘅參考資料）！
